qas.question: What was the guiding ideal of translators throughout the 18th century?
If a translator didn't understand something in a text or thought it too boring to present to readers, what did they do with it?
What did translators of this time assume was better than the actual text they were translating?
How much did the translators care about scholarship?

answers.text: no more than had their predecessors

qas.question: What was the guiding ideal of translators throughout the 14th century?
What did translators of this time assume was worse than the actual text they were translating?

plausible_answers.text: no more than had their predecessors

qas.question: How much did the translators avoid scholarship?
What did James Macpherson never "translate" from?

context: Throughout the 18th century, the watchword of translators was <a0_0><b5_0>ease of reading<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Whatever they did not understand in a text, or thought might bore readers, they <a1_0>omitted<a1_0/>. They cheerfully assumed that <a2_0><b6_0>their own style of expression<b6_0/><a2_0/> was the best, and that texts should be made to conform to it in translation. For scholarship they cared <a3_0><b7_0>no more than had their predecessors<b7_0/><a3_0/>, and they did not shrink from making translations from translations in third languages, or from languages that they hardly knew, or—as in the case of James Macpherson's "translations" of Ossian—from texts that were actually of the "translator's" <a4_0><b8_0>own composition<b8_0/><a4_0/>.
